speaker: Javier M. Gonzales
vclaim: "The study after study showed that the cities of refuge do not lead to an increase in crime because of the presence of undocumented persons."
date: stated on November 16, 2016 in an interview on The Kelly File:
title: The mayor of Santa Fe defending the cities of refuge says that studies do not show an increase in crime.
text: The number of conservatives across America is doubled by the decisions of their cities to act as a refuge for illegal immigrants living in the country, despite the promise of President-elect Donald Trump to reduce federal funding. Javier González, Mayor of Santa Fe, N.M., recently appeared in Fox News, in defence of his city's position not to assist federal officials in enforcing immigration laws. Megan Kelly, host of Fox News, Kelly's file, González, asked about criticism of cities like Santa Fe, claiming that "reserve cities" attracted criminals. Gonzales said that his city gave priority to prosecuting persons who committed violent crimes, regardless of their immigration status. There was also evidence that the cities of refuge were not magnets for crime. "The study after the study showed that the cities of refuge did not lead to an increase in crime because of the presence of undocumented persons," González Nov 16 said. Is that right? "Protected cities" notwithstanding the name, the Holy City is not always a city, it can be a town, province or other jurisdiction. There is no federal law defining shelters, but this term generally applies to places that have policies or orders limiting their assistance to federal immigration authorities seeking to arrest migrants in the country and to deport them illegally. The concept of modern refuge stems from the 1980s when churches opened their doors to shelter Central America, who fled violence in their countries and lived illegally in the United States, fearing deportation. The new shelter movement was launched in 2007, with places of worship throughout the country becoming a haven for migrants facing deportation. There are at least 50 communities throughout the United States offering refuge. Churches, schools, hospitals and public demonstrations, such as rallies and marches, by immigration officials are regarded as sensitive sites, where enforcement procedures are generally avoided but may be carried out with the consent of a supervisor or under "intuitive circumstances." The exact number of jurisdictions considered as refuge cities fluctuates with the adoption or abandonment of policy spaces. Policy details also vary from place to place. The mayor of New Orleans, for example, says the term "protected city" does not apply to his city, but some critics say she has practices. Lena Graber, a private project lawyer at the Legal Resource Centre for Migrants, estimated that there were more than 500 provinces and 38 cities with policies that did not help enforce immigration and customs laws in the United States. Federal laws provide that governments or state and local government officials may not prohibit the keeping of immigration records or exchange them with other local, state or federal entities, according to a report issued by the Congressional Research Service in 2009. However, if the judicial authorities did not ask individuals about their immigration status, then they did not have the information that could be kept and shared, the report said. Supporters of the cities of refuge say that not questioning people about their immigration status builds trust between the police and the community and encourages the population to report crimes. If an undocumented immigrant is arrested for non-immigration, he can still be charged, tried and convicted for that crime, as Gruber said. It is argued that cities of refuge attract illegal migration and undermine law enforcement. On February 1, 2021, Tom Cotton mentioned in an interview with Fox and friends "Many of these arriving immigrants, we have no way of checking their background for either health or security." • 3 February 2021, an offence committed illegally by a person in the country would have been a crime that could have been avoided by the removal of that person, as said Ira Mulman, spokesman for the American Immigration Reform Union, who seeks to reduce immigration levels. What studies show that the Santa Fe Mayor's Office sent multiple studies that found that immigrants were less likely to commit crimes than people born in the United States. They also highlighted a report by the United States Migration Board, a pro-immigrant group, which states that this applies to immigrants here legally and illegally. But there is not much research on the cities of refuge and their effects on crime, as experts have said. Precautionary decrees had been in place for over 30 years, but until recently, sociologists had only been able to study their impact on crime rates, as stated by Elizabeth V. Cohen, an assistant professor of political science at Syracuse University. A 2009 study from the University of California, Berkeley School of Law, refers to Austin, Texas, as an example where cooperation between immigrant communities and law enforcement has led to increased crime reporting and lower levels of crime. Other examples of low crime rates due to policies favourable to migrants are also included in this 2012 study. Research also indicates that reporting of crimes - especially in communities with a high proportion of migrants - is likely to have a negative impact when local officials implement immigration law enforcement practices, as was said by Charles E. Cobrin, Professor of Criminology at the University of California, Irvine. Cohen said that a study carried out by collaborators at the University of Chicago and the University of New York in 2014 on whether the immigration law enforcement programme known as safe communities had reduced crime showed that there had been no significant increase in crime in the cities of refuge during the start of the programme. In the framework of the (substituted) programme, when a person was detained at the police station or prison, the information of that person was eventually sent to the FBI and the Ministry of Internal Security for information on the immigration register of the person. Recently, researchers at the University of California in Riverside and the Healyen College found that asylum policies did not affect crime rates in any way. The study included an analysis of violent crimes, property crimes and rape. The October 2016 study said: "Precautionary policies in terms of leading to crime do not seem to be a problem." "In fact... almost all research that assesses the links between migration and criminality finds a reversible relationship." Trump campaigned against asylum policies by provoking incidents of undocumented migrants in these cities who commit violent crimes, such as the alleged shooting of Catherine Steinel by a Mexican citizen in San Francisco. However, we have found no evidence of the existence of cities of refuge leading to an increase in crime. Qualitative information on asylum practices indicates that it is useful for criminal law enforcement practices, as stated by Phil Torre, a law lecturer with the clinical programme on migration and refugees at Harvard University, and a lawyer supervising the Harvard migration project. Tori said that the increase in crime in a holy city could be caused by factors unrelated to the undocumented inhabitants of that city. For example, the increase in the city's population could explain the increase in criminal arrests in general. The Governor, González, said, "The post-study study showed that the cities of refuge do not lead to an increase in crime because of the presence of undocumented persons." The data behind González ' s view of the cities of refuge are not as conclusive or broad as he described. However, a recent study by academic researchers found that asylum policies did not affect crime rates. Other studies have found a decrease in crime as a result of cooperation between immigrant communities and law enforcement. Researchers also say that migrants, including those in the country illegally, are less likely to commit crimes than the population born in the country. The González statement exaggerates the scope of the research on this subject but is on the right track.
